title-group.article-title: An analysis of preferences for hazardous substances free products: manufacturing, use and end of life of mobile phones

contrib-group.aff: Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, New Delhi, India

author-notes.corresp: Rajendra Kumar Kaushal, Department of Civil Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi-110 016, India Email: rajendra.kaushal02@gmail.com

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: Waste electrical and electronic equipment

abstract.p: Electronic communication devices such as mobile phones pose significant environmental risks when disposed of after the end of their useful life. Mobile communication devices are one of the fastest growing contributors to the electronic waste (e-waste) stream. Recent legislative pressure and increasing awareness about the environmental risk associated with the hazardous components of the electronic products warrants the manufacturers to reduce or replace the hazardous materials with alternatives. The present study analyses the economic consequences of reducing or replacing these hazardous materials and the possible response of the consumers. A strategic game theory model has been applied in this paper for manufacturer and consumers considering the cost difference between hazardous substances free (HSF) and hazardous substance (HS) mobile. Results suggest that the HSF mobiles can be a preferred choice of the manufacturers as well as consumers if the cost of disposal of HS mobiles can be internalized and a marginal incentive (e.g. 0.9% for a cost difference to 5%, and 5.3% for a cost difference to 10%) is given. The study further highlights the need for realizing the fact that passing on the incentives to the consumers in order to promote schemes for return back to manufacturer at its end of life for effective reuse and recycling gives higher returns.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Mobile phones, due to short life span, are one of the fastest growing contributors to electronic waste (e-waste). Large quantities of mobile waste are generated globally and are in most cases inappropriately managed especially in the developing countries. An average mobile phone contains over 40 elements including precious metals such as silver (250 mg), gold (24 mg) and palladium (9 mg) with copper (9 g) as its main metal component (StEP, 2009). Out of more than 20 metallic elements representing 35–40% of the total weight of a device, 12 elements are identified as being highly hazardous whereas, 12 are considered to be less harmful elements (Wu et al., 2008). Lead, which is mainly used as solder in mobile phones, is of immense concern. The brominated flame retardants which are embedded in the plastics to reduce the risk of fire are another hazardous component of cell phones. Many of these toxic substances, including antimony (Sb), arsenic (As), beryllium (Be), cadmium (Cd), copper (Cu), lead (Pb), nickel (Ni), and zinc (Zn), can persist as well as bio-accumulative toxins (PBTs) that may increase chances of cancer, apart from several other health implications including, reproductive, neurological, and developmental disorders (Bhuie et al. 2004). Generally, the PBTs contained in mobile phones are present in the printed wiring boards and the liquid–crystal displays.

There are a number of regulatory initiatives, such as Wastes from Electric and Electronic Equipment 2002, the European Union’s Restriction of Hazardous Substances, Eco-design of Energy-using Products 2003 directive and revised directives published in 2008 on electrical and electronic equipment in order to tackle the fast-increasing waste stream of such products and put pressure on manufacturers to make them responsible for the end-of-life (EoL) of their products. Gehin et al. (2008) reported that Japan has started to pursue aggressively the removal of lead from the manufacturing process of electronic components. Ministry of Environment and Forests (MoEF, 2010), Government of India has also introduced E-waste (Management and Handling) Rules 2010, which will come into effect from May 2012. The aim of these directives and regulations is to prevent pollution by hazardous substances and thus protect human health and reduce environmental damage.

In recent times with regard to the production of hazardous substance free (HSF) electronic products, manufacturers are facing serious challenges due to the emerging issues of hazardous substances (HS) management. Manufacturers are increasingly considering the product design strategies, which are economic as well as environmentally friendly. This requires the manufacturers to reduce the use of HS materials in their products to ensure that the end product meets directive’s requirements. Wang et al. (2010) state that it usually costs the producers more to use the HSF material, for example, the price of the leaded tin is approximately 60 Yuan kg−1, whereas lead-free solder wire costs around 260 Yuan kg−1 (1 Yuan = 0.16 US$). Hence replacing the HS with HSF materials in product supply chain will have significant impact on the overall cost of the product.

However, by implementing certain strategies, this increased cost of the product can be compensated to the manufacturer as well as the consumer since they will be contributing towards reducing the environmental issues at the time of end-of-life disposal of a product. The basic premise of this study is to seek the policies in such a manner that the overall profit of manufacturer and the cost paid by the consumer remains in dynamic balance with the likely disposal penalty at the time of disposal and hence inculcating a cooperation instead of the conflict of paying more for a cause of saving environment.

Game theory, originated with the revolutionary work of Neumann and Morgenstern (1944), is a mathematical tool for analysing the conflict and cooperation between rational decision-makers. In game theory each decision-maker plays the game to optimize his own objective, knowing that other player’s decisions affect his objective value and that his decision affects other’s payoffs and decisions. Nash equilibrium is a solution from which no player can unilaterally deviate in order to improve his/her payoff (Osborne and Rubinstein, 1994).

This study applied the game theory to create the strategic game model between manufacturer and consumer each having two strategies. The proposed game theory-based model can serve as a powerful technique for analysing the strategies for the stakeholders for creating a win–win situation for manufacturers and consumers as well as the environment.

sec.title: Mobile phones: a compositional overview
sec.p: A typical mobile phone is composed of a battery, a keyboard, a screen and a printed wiring board weighing 100 g or less (without battery), and are powered by a small battery (average weight of 23 g) (Nnorom and Osinbanjo, 2009). Mobile phones are relatively smaller in size as compare to other electronic products but because of their material composition and their potentially large numbers, their disposal into the domestic waste stream is problematic. It has been reported that the amount of cadmium from one mobile phone battery is sufficient to pollute 600 000 L of water (He et al., 2006). Hazardous materials used in the mobile can pollute the air when burned in incinerators or leach into soil and drinking water sources when buried in landfills (StEP, 2009).

It is possible to change the manufacturing of a HS mobile phone into a HSF mobile phone by removing or reducing the HS materials. Reduction of HS materials may be more economical than completely removing them because the available alternatives for some of the HS materials are costlier (Table 1) (Lincoln et al., 2005). Hence, if the quantity of HS materials in a mobile phone can be reduced to below their threshold limit, that mobile phone can be considered as a HSF mobile.

tr.td: In casings, PWBs, connectors, wiring, and cabling.
Ammonium polyphosphate, aluminium tri- hydroxide, resorcinol di- phenyl phosphate
Can contaminate drinking water and adversely impacts the central nervous and immune systems of human body.
In anticorrosive coatings on metals, primers for coated metals, hard chrome, and metalizing plastics.
Trivalent chromium, high-velocity oxygenated fuel, organic polymer films

sec.title: Market based e-waste strategies around the world
sec.p: E-waste management is being practised in many countries by adopting legal and economic tools which provide financial resources to implement and operate these systems. The organized systems for the collection, recycling, disposal and monitoring are available in many of the countries. For example, computer monitors, televisions and several consumer electronic devices are banned from disposal into the landfills in California and Massachusetts (Davis and Smith, 2003), hence promoting reuse, recycle and treatment.

Kahhat et al. (2008) reported that in Japan consumers must pay an EoL fee which is a pre-disposal fee that covers part of the recycling and transportation costs. Furthermore, for all the computers sold after October 2003, prices contain an invisible non-refundable recycling fee or an advance recycling fee (ARF). In Taiwan, manufacturers have to pay for collection and recycling costs of obsolete e-products and contribute to a national recycling fund which is used for various purposes such as subsidies to proper recycling (Chung et al., 2009).

In South Korea, at the beginning of the year, manufacturers and importers have to deposit with the government a recycling fee which is partially refundable at the end of the year according to the number of electronic devices they recycled over that year. Consumers pay a collection fee depending on the type and condition of the equipment (Milanez and Buhrs, 2009). The Swiss design system is based on an ARF which producers pay at the time of sale or import of any equipment (Sinha-Khetriwal et al., 2009).

Material and financial flows of e-waste in India are shown in Figure 1. In India, collectors generally pay customers for their old appliances, which are in demand for a strong recycling network (Sinha-Khetriwal et al. 2005). Josheph (2007) reported that in India, the growth rate of the mobile phones (80%) is very high in comparison with that of personal computers (20%) and televisions (18%) and the willingness of public to pay extra fee for e-waste management ranges from 3.4 to 5% for the mobile phones.

caption.p: Material and financial flows of e-waste in India.

sec.p: The implementation of a take back service for e-waste is in the growing stage in India and requires policy support. Take back schemes in India are being practised by HCL, WIPRO, Nokia, Acer, Motorola, and LG (Greenpeace, 2008). However, the overall e-waste management situation in India warrants a more involved role of the market-based mechanisms with the participatory role and responsibility of all important stakeholders.

sec.title: Application of decision-making tool
sec.p: Casey et al. (2007) reported the application of game theory to the lifecycle of bottle packaging, and presents a framework for an analysis of the choice between refillable and disposable bottles. Xin-Jun and Qing-Li (2008) used game theory to analyse the maximization of profits with one manufacturer and two retailers in a closed loop supply chain. Ying-Ying et al. (2009) studied the price decisions and incentive mechanism of the three-level reverse supply chain (RSC) model included a manufacturer, a maintenance centre and a retailer.

Liu et al. (2011) analysed the behaviour of enterprise, government and the consumer in terms of joining the green supply system using game theory. Wang et al. (2010) used the game theory to create a mixed-strategy static game model of electronic manufacturers and suppliers. Zhang and Jin (2011) have presented a pricing model of RSC based on closed-loop supply chain and game theory. Barari et al. (2012) have presented a two-player synergetic alliance with the focus on maximizing economic profits by leveraging upon the product’s greenness. Gao and Jin (2011) have used the game theory, for a RSC consisting of one manufacturer and two distributors and concluded that the maximum profit can be obtained with the three-member enterprise cartelization.

Learning from the experiences of different countries in implementing their various policies for successful e-waste management, there is a need to develop a set of strategies that can provide a self-propelling market-based mechanism and win–win situation to all important stakeholders. The proposed game model for manufacturer and consumer can be useful for finding such a set of Nash-equilibrium strategies which motivate them to recycle HSF mobile phones.

sec.title: Game model for manufacturer and consumer
sec.p: An extensive-form game is a specification of a game in game theory, which represents the sequencing of players’ possible moves, their choices at every decision point, the information each player has about the other player’s moves when he makes a decision, and his payoffs for all possible game outcomes. The manufacturer has two strategies: uses HS or uses HSF material in manufacturing of mobile phones (Table 2). However, any manufacturer will be indifferent about choosing HS or HSF material products for manufacturing if its profit remains same in both cases. The manufacturer can give incentives to the consumer (Figure 1) for product return through a ‘buy back approach’ whereby old electronic goods are collected and a discount could be given on new products purchased by the consumer. Furthermore, manufacturer can adopt a new fee mechanism as ARF, from the consumer, for EoL management of mobile waste in HS mobiles, whereas it can be relaxed in the case of HSF mobiles. It will be helpful in decreasing the financial burden on the manufacturer associated with using HSF materials. The consumer may have two strategies for its mobile phone waste: either to choose land-disposal or return it back to manufacturer or to its agents in a take-back scheme (Table 2). According the existence of Nash equilibrium the mixed strategy game model between manufacturer and consumer is developed as shown in Table 2, where α presents the probability of manufacturer using HSF materials and β presents the probability that the consumer will choose LD. ΔC is the cost difference between HSF and HS mobiles, πM, πC are the payoffs of the manufacturer and consumer, respectively.

caption.p: Mixed strategy game model between manufacturer and consumer.

sec.p: The manufacturer’s payoff as a function of the mixed-strategy profile is:
For given β the expected payoff of manufacturer comes under two strategies use HSF (α = 1) and use HS (α = 1):

If the probability of consumer’s land disposal selection is greater than β (Equation (2)) the manufacturer will select the strategy of using HSF materials. In contrast, if it is less than β it is optimal for the manufacturer to use materials with HS. If the probability is equal to β, the manufacturer will randomly select the strategy.
Similarly, consumer’s payoff as a function of the mixed-strategy profile
For given α the expected payoff of consumer comes under two strategies LD (β = 1) and RB (β = 1)
Solution πC(1,α) = πC(0,α) implies that

It shows that if the probability of manufacturer using HSF materials is greater than α (Equation (4)), the consumer will choose RB, however, if it is less than α, it is optimal for the manufacturer to choose LD. It is to be noted that in case the probability is equal to α, manufacturer will choose the strategy randomly. The Nash-equilibrium of the game depends on the payoffs of the players or on the parameters that affects the payoffs of the players.

sec.title: Pay-offs or utility formulation for players
sec.p: The parameters such as ARF (EP) from consumer, incentive from government (IGM) and selling price of recycled material (SR) at EoL disposal of mobile phone are positive payoffs (defined as profits) to manufacturer. The collection fee (CC), recycling fee (RF) and incentive to consumer in a take-back scheme (IMC) for mobile phone at its EoL are negative payoffs to the manufacturer. Similarly incentive from manufacturer in a take-back scheme (IMC) is positive payoff to consumer while transportation cost (TC), ARF (EP) and penalty to the government for land disposal of mobile waste (IGC) are negative payoffs for the consumer for both HSF and HS mobiles.
The payoffs for the players were calculated using following equations:
Payoff of the manufacturer
Payoff of the consumer
and j = 1 or 2, k = 1 or 2 as each player will select its single strategy at a given time

sec.title: Basic assumptions
sec.p: The following assumptions have been made for the proposed game model:

list-item.p: All the stakeholders are rational players. The stakeholders are expected to choose a strategy which maximizes their gains.
There is no upper limit on the capacities of the collection, reuse, treatment and disposal facilities.

Penalty will be charged by the government where the consumer chooses the land-disposal option to minimize the land-disposal of the waste. Penalty for land-disposal of HS mobile is higher in comparison with HSF mobile waste.
The consumer will pay the penalty charged by the government.
Government will provide incentives to manufacturer for manufacturing HSF mobiles and no incentive for HS mobiles.
Manufacturer will pay the incentive to the consumer in a take-back scheme.
Incentive will be given to consumer only in the case where the consumer chooses the return back option.
Manufacturer will pay the collection fee and recycling fee of mobile waste.
Selling price of recycled material will be taken by manufacturer.

sec.p: In addition, the recycling of a HS mobile is considered costlier than a HSF mobile because it will require more careful and skilled recycling. Transportation cost and collection charges are considered to be the same for both HSF and HS mobiles. The resale price of the recycled material of the HSF mobile is taken to be higher in comparison with the HS mobile. The incentive to the consumer from the manufacturer in a take-back scheme for a HSF mobile is taken to be more in comparison with an HS mobile to promote the sale of the HSF mobile. The assumed values of various parameters are shown in Table 3 for both HSF and HS mobile.

caption.p: Parameter values in the game model

tr.th: Assumed extra cost for HSF mobile (X)
X1 = 5% of cost of HS mobile
X2 = 10% of cost of HS mobile
X3 = 15% of cost of HS mobile
X4 = 20% of cost of HS mobile

tr.td: Incentive return to Consumer from Manufacturer (IMC) *
Penalty to consumer in land disposal by government (IGC)*

sec.title: Example problem

list-item.p: Consider the cost of a HS mobile as 200 US$.
Assumed ARF for a HS mobile = 3.0% of cost = 6 US$
Total actual cost of HS mobile = 206 US$

sec.p: If the cost of HSF mobile is taken 5.0% more of the cost of HS mobile then:

list-item.p: Extra cost paid by consumer for HSF mobile as compare to HS mobile ΔC = 210 − 206 = 4 US$.

sec.p: Now if this ΔC could be recovered or regained by the consumer, also if the profit of manufacturer remains same for both HSF and HS mobiles, the manufacturer would like to produce HSF mobiles and the consumer would prefer to purchase a HSF mobile. The values of incentive to manufacturer from government (Y1, Y2, Y3, Y4) and incentive return to consumer from manufacturer (Z1, Z2, Z3, Z4) have been found for assumed cost differences (X1, X2, X3, and X4, respectively) using a two player non-cooperative extensive game with manufacturer and consumer as players. Game-trees for non-cooperative game (extensive form) for two players have been generated using software ‘GAMBIT’ for each case. For example, the game-tree for one of the cases, for example, Y3 = 5.40% for X2 = 10.0% is shown in Figure 2. The payoffs for strategic moves are shown at their terminal nodes. The probabilities of selecting each of the actions are displayed above the respective branch of the game tree.

caption.p: Extensive game for IGM (Y3) = 5.4% for X2 = 10.0%.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Considering the cost of a HSF mobile to be 5, 10, 15 and 20% more than the cost of a HS mobile the Nash-equilibrium strategies with respective payoffs for manufacturer and consumer are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Results of mixed strategy game model.

tr.th: Cost of mobile and cost difference (US$) (a)
Cost difference (% of cost of HS mobile) (b)
ARF (3% of cost of HS mobile) (US$) (d)
Total extra cost paid for HSF (US$) (j) = (i) − (h)

fn.label: a
fn.p: HSF: Hazardous Substance FREE; HS: Hazardous Substance; RB: Return Back; LD: Land Disposal.

sec.title: Incentive to manufacturer
sec.p: From Table 4 it can be seen that, for X1 = 5%, at Y1 = 0.80% the Nash-equilibrium strategies are HS and RB with payoffs of 0 and −4.0 US$ for manufacturer and consumer, respectively. At Y2 = 0.90% the Nash-equilibrium strategies are HSF or HS and RB with payoffs (0 and 4.09 US$) and (0 and −4.0 US$) and at Y3 = 1.0% the strategies are HSF and RB with payoffs of 0.21 and 4.09 US$, respectively, for manufacturer and consumer. It implies that if the incentive from government to manufacturer is equal to or more than 0.90% of the cost of the HSF mobile, the the manufacturer’s profit remains the same or increases and the consumer recovers the extra cost (4.0 US$) paid for a HSF mobile by getting the payoff of 4.09 US$.

It appears that for a cost difference of 5% of the cost of a HS mobile, if the government gives an incentive of at least 0.90% on the cost of the HSF mobile to a manufacturer, only then will the manufacturer prefer manufacturing HSF mobiles and the consumer will prefer the HSF mobile which can be returned back to the manufacturer at its EoL. In other words, the manufacturer will prefer the manufacturing of HSF mobiles in place of HS mobiles only if the incentive from government is at least 0.9% of the cost of a HSF mobile.

Similarly for a cost difference of 10, 15 and 20% if the government gives incentives of 5.30, 9.40 and 13% or more, respectively, to the manufacturer, the manufacturer will choose HSF mobile manufacturing and the consumer will prefer to return it back to the manufacturer at its EoL in a take-back scheme (Figure 3). As, at these incentives of 5.30, 9.40 and 13% to the manufacturer, the payoffs to the manufacturer remains the same (0 US$) for both HS and HSF mobile manufacturing, whereas the payoffs to the consumer are 14.06, 24.22 and 34 US$, respectively. The extra cost paid by the consumer for a HSF mobile are 14.0, 24.0 and 34 US$, respectively, for cost differences of 10, 15 and 20%. This suggests that the consumer recovers the extra cost paid for a HSF mobile with its payoffs.

sec.title: Incentive to consumer for a HSF mobile (IMC)
sec.p: It can be seen from Table 4 that, for X1 = 5%, the Nash-equilibrium strategies at Z2 = 2.9% are HSF and RB with payoffs of 0 and 4.09 US$, respectively, for manufacturer and consumer. This suggests that for a cost difference of 5% of the cost of a HS mobile, the manufacturer will prefer HSF mobile manufacturing if the value of the incentive for the consumer is less than or equal to 2.9% of the cost of the HSF mobile. However, when Z1 = 2.8% the Nash-equilibrium strategies are HSF and RB with payoffs 0.21 and 3.88 US$, respectively, for the manufacturer and consumer. It suggest that at Z1 = 2.8%, the consumer cannot recover its extra cost (4.0 US$) paid for a HSF mobile. At Z3 = 3% the Nash-equilibrium strategies are HS and RB with payoffs of 0 and −4.0 US$, respectively, for manufacturer and consumer. It recommends that the manufacturer will prefer to produce HS mobiles if the incentive to the consumer from the manufacturer for a HSF mobile is 3.0%. Therefore, the manufacturer will prefer HSF mobile manufacturing and the consumer will prefer the HSF mobile to return back to the manufacturer at its EoL only when the incentive to the consumer is 2.9% of the cost of the HSF mobile for the cost difference of 5%.

Similarly for a cost difference of 10, 15 and 20%, the manufacturer will prefer HSF mobile manufacturing and the consumer will prefer the HSF mobile to return back to manufacturer at its EoL only when the incentive to the consumer is 7.3, 11.4 and 15% of the cost of the HSF mobile (Figure 3). As, at these incentives of 7.3, 11.4 and 15% to the consumer, the payoffs to the manufacturer remain the same (0 US$) for both HS and HSF mobile manufacturing, whereas the payoffs to the consumer are 14.06, 24.22 and 34 US$, respectively. The extra cost paid by the consumer for a HSF mobile are 14, 24 and 34 US$, respectively, for cost difference of 10, 15 and 20%. It suggests that with these incentives the consumer can recover the extra cost paid for a HSF mobile with its payoffs.

sec.title: Incentive to consumer for HS mobile (IMC’)
sec.p: For a HS mobile costing 200 US$, Nash-equilibrium suggests that the manufacturer will prefer to produce HSF mobiles if they have to give an incentive of more than 2.0% of the cost of the HS mobile to the consumer. If the value of the incentive is less than 2.0%, the manufacturer will prefer to produce HS mobiles.

sec.title: ARF for HS mobile (EP)
sec.p: For a HS mobile costing 200 US$, Nash-equilibrium suggests that the manufacturers will not prefer the production of a HS mobile and choose HSF mobile production if they get an ARF that is less than 3% of the cost of the HS mobile from the consumer. If the ARF is more than 3%, the manufacturer’s choice will be HS mobile production.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the present study a game theoretic approach has been applied, considering two key stakeholder manufacturer and consumer as players, for replacing the HS mobile phone with HSF mobile phone without compromising their profits. A set of policies can be found which satisfy both the players and create win-win situation to them. Strategic Nash-equilibrium recommends some initiatives, which can be implemented to promote the manufacturing of HSF mobile in the following manner.

list-item.p: The government can impose some penalty on the land disposal of mobile waste to encourage the recycling of mobiles. This penalty should be more in the case of land disposal of HS mobiles in comparison with the land disposal of HSF mobiles.

The government can give an incentive to manufacturers for producing the HSF mobiles through relaxation in taxes, etc. and no such incentive for producing HS mobiles. The values of that incentive were found by considering the cost difference between HSF and HS mobile phones of 5, 10, 15 and 20% of the cost of a HS mobile. A closer look at mixed strategy Nash-equilibrium suggests that for the cost difference of 5%, if the government gives an incentive of 0.9% of the cost of the HSF mobile or more to the manufacturer, only then will the manufacturer prefer HSF mobile manufacturing and the consumer will prefer the HSF mobile to return back to the manufacturer at its EoL. Similarly, for cost differences of 10, 15 and 20% the manufacturer will choose HSF mobile manufacturing and the consumer will prefer to return it back to the manufacturer at its EoL only if the government gives to the manufacturer an incentive of at least of 5.3, 9.4 and 13%, respectively, of the cost of a HSF mobile.

The manufacturer can promote a take-back scheme for mobile phones with some incentives to the consumer. These incentives should be more for a HSF mobile in comparison with a HS mobile phone to attract the consumer towards the HSF mobile. It was found that the manufacturer would prefer HSF mobile manufacturing without compromising its profit and the consumer would prefer the HSF mobile to return back to the manufacturer at its EoL only when the incentive to the consumer is 2.9% of the cost of the HSF mobile for the cost difference of 5%. Similarly for cost differences of 10, 15 and 20%, the corresponding values of incentives to the consumer were 7.3, 11.4 and 15% of the cost of the HSF mobile, respectively.

For a HS mobile costing 200 US$, manufacturers will prefer to produce HSF mobiles if they have to give an incentive of more than 2.0% of the cost of the HS mobile to the consumer in a take-back scheme. If the value of the incentive is less than 2.0%, manufacturers will prefer to produce HS mobiles.

Manufacturers can impose an ARF to the consumer at the time of purchase of a HS mobile phone for it EoL management, whereas there should be no ARF for a HSF mobile phone. For a HS mobile costing 200 US$, Nash-equilibrium suggests that manufacturers will not prefer the production of HS mobiles and will choose HSF mobile production if they get an ARF from the consumer that is less than 3% of the cost of the HS mobile. If the ARF is more than 3%, the manufacturers’ choice will be HS mobile production.

sec.p: The proposed methodology and example problems demonstrate the usefulness of the game theory-based model for taking strategic decisions. The discussions on the findings of this study help in interpreting the results and thus help in formulating better policies to promote reuse and recycling, and thus reduce the environmental and human health-related issues with the e-waste streams.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
